content.question: Read each question carefully. Write your response in the space provided for each part of each question. Answers must be written out in paragraph form. Outlines, bulleted lists, or diagrams alone are not acceptable and will not be scored. The <math alttext="S I R T 3" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>SIRT3</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> protein has been reported to increase the growth of certain types of cancer cells. Researchers studying the metabolism and development of stomach cancer cells investigated the potential role of the <math alttext="S I R T 3" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>SIRT3</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> protein in these cells. In the first investigation, the researchers quantified the relative amount of <math alttext="S I R T 3" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>SIRT3</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> in normal stomach cells and in each of four different lines of stomach cancer cells (Figure 1). Using data from a group of <math alttext="100" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>100</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> patients with stomach cancer, the researchers also analyzed the relative amount of <math alttext="S I R T 3" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>SIRT3</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> protein detected in samples of the cancer cells and in normal cells immediately adjacent to the cancer cells (Figure 2). Figure 1. <math alttext="S I R T 3" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>SIRT3</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> protein levels in normal stomach cells (<math alttext="N S" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>NS</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>) and stomach cancer cell lines from four different patients (<math alttext="S C 1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>SC-1</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="S C 2" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>SC-2</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="S C 3" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>SC-3</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="S C 4" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>SC-4</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>), shown relative to the level in normal stomach cells (<math alttext="N S" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>NS</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>). Error bars represent <math alttext="plus or minus S E sub x bar" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mo>±</mo><mtext>SE</mtext></mrow><mrow><mover><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>¯</mo></mrow></mover></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>. Figure 2. The number of patients, from <math alttext="100" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>100</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> tested, whose stomach cancer cells or normal stomach cells adjacent to the cancer cells express high, low, or no <math alttext="S I R T 3" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>SIRT3</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> protein In the second investigation, the researchers grew four groups of stomach cells in petri dishes containing nutrient broth:• <math alttext="N S" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>NS</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, normal stomach cells• <math alttext="S C 1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>SC-1</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, a line of stomach cancer cells that the researchers had examined for <math alttext="S I R T 3" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>SIRT3</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> expression• <math alttext="S C plus R N A" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>SC</mtext><mo>+</mo><mtext>RNA</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, the <math alttext="S C 1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>SC-1</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> line of stomach cancer cells to which a plasmid was added that encodes a small <math alttext="R N A" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>RNA</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> complementary to a portion of the <math alttext="S I R T 3" overflow="scroll"><mstyle mathvariant="italic"><mrow><mtext>SIRT3</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> <math alttext="m R N A" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>mRNA</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>. When these small <math alttext="R N A's" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>RNAs</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> bind to the complementary portion of <math alttext="S I R T 3" overflow="scroll"><mstyle mathvariant="italic"><mrow><mtext>SIRT3</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> <math alttext="m R N A" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>mRNA</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, the <math alttext="S I R T 3" overflow="scroll"><mstyle mathvariant="italic"><mrow><mtext>SIRT3</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> <math alttext="m R N A" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>mRNA</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> is broken down rather than translated.• <math alttext="S C plus plasmid" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>SC</mtext><mo>+</mo><mtext>plasmid</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, the <math alttext="S C 1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>SC-1</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> line of stomach cancer cells to which a plasmid was added that does NOT encode the complementary small <math alttext="R N A" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>RNA</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> After <math alttext="24" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>24</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> hours of growth, the researchers measured several indicators of metabolism by an equal number of all four cell groups: glucose uptake, lactic acid production, and the level of cytoplasmic <math alttext="A T P" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>ATP</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> production in the presence of a compound that blocks the electron transport chain (Figure 3). The values were calculated relative to the values obtained for normal stomach cells. Figure 3. Glucose uptake, lactic acid production, and cytoplasmic <math alttext="A T P" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>ATP</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> levels in stomach cells. <math alttext="N S" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>NS</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, normal stomach cells; <math alttext="S C 1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>SC-1</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, stomach cancer cells; <math alttext="S C plus plasmid" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>SC</mtext><mtext> + plasmid</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="S C 1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>SC-1</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> cells with added plasmid only; <math alttext="S C plus R N A" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>SC</mtext><mo>+</mo><mtext>RNA</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="S C 1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>SC-1</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> cells with added plasmid encoding small <math alttext="R N A" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>RNA</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> complementary to a portion of <math alttext="S I R T 3" overflow="scroll"><mstyle mathvariant="italic"><mrow><mtext>SIRT3</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>. Error bars represent <math alttext="plus or minus S E sub x bar" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mo>±</mo><mtext>SE</mtext></mrow><mrow><mover><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>¯</mo></mrow></mover></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>. (a) Explain why an <math alttext="m R N A" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>mRNA</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> transcribed from the template strand of the <math alttext="S I R T 3" overflow="scroll"><mstyle mathvariant="italic"><mrow><mtext>SIRT3</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> gene in normal stomach (<math alttext="N S" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>NS</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>) cells is translated to produce a <math alttext="S I R T 3" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>SIRT3</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> protein of correct sequence, but if an <math alttext="m R N A" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>mRNA</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> were transcribed from the nontemplate strand of the <math alttext="S I R T 3" overflow="scroll"><mstyle mathvariant="italic"><mrow><mtext>SIRT3</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> gene in these cells, it would not produce a <math alttext="S I R T 3" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>SIRT3</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> protein of correct sequence.

frqParts.text: Read each question carefully. Write your response in the space provided for each part of each question. Answers must be written out in paragraph form. Outlines, bulleted lists, or diagrams alone are not acceptable and will not be scored. The <math alttext="S I R T 3" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>SIRT3</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> protein has been reported to increase the growth of certain types of cancer cells. Researchers studying the metabolism and development of stomach cancer cells investigated the potential role of the <math alttext="S I R T 3" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>SIRT3</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> protein in these cells. In the first investigation, the researchers quantified the relative amount of <math alttext="S I R T 3" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>SIRT3</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> in normal stomach cells and in each of four different lines of stomach cancer cells (Figure 1). Using data from a group of <math alttext="100" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>100</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> patients with stomach cancer, the researchers also analyzed the relative amount of <math alttext="S I R T 3" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>SIRT3</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> protein detected in samples of the cancer cells and in normal cells immediately adjacent to the cancer cells (Figure 2). Figure 1. <math alttext="S I R T 3" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>SIRT3</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> protein levels in normal stomach cells (<math alttext="N S" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>NS</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>) and stomach cancer cell lines from four different patients (<math alttext="S C 1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>SC-1</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="S C 2" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>SC-2</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="S C 3" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>SC-3</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="S C 4" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>SC-4</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>), shown relative to the level in normal stomach cells (<math alttext="N S" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>NS</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>). Error bars represent <math alttext="plus or minus S E sub x bar" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mo>±</mo><mtext>SE</mtext></mrow><mrow><mover><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>¯</mo></mrow></mover></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>. Figure 2. The number of patients, from <math alttext="100" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>100</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> tested, whose stomach cancer cells or normal stomach cells adjacent to the cancer cells express high, low, or no <math alttext="S I R T 3" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>SIRT3</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> protein In the second investigation, the researchers grew four groups of stomach cells in petri dishes containing nutrient broth:• <math alttext="N S" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>NS</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, normal stomach cells• <math alttext="S C 1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>SC-1</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, a line of stomach cancer cells that the researchers had examined for <math alttext="S I R T 3" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>SIRT3</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> expression• <math alttext="S C plus R N A" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>SC</mtext><mo>+</mo><mtext>RNA</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, the <math alttext="S C 1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>SC-1</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> line of stomach cancer cells to which a plasmid was added that encodes a small <math alttext="R N A" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>RNA</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> complementary to a portion of the <math alttext="S I R T 3" overflow="scroll"><mstyle mathvariant="italic"><mrow><mtext>SIRT3</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> <math alttext="m R N A" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>mRNA</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>. When these small <math alttext="R N A's" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>RNAs</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> bind to the complementary portion of <math alttext="S I R T 3" overflow="scroll"><mstyle mathvariant="italic"><mrow><mtext>SIRT3</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> <math alttext="m R N A" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>mRNA</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, the <math alttext="S I R T 3" overflow="scroll"><mstyle mathvariant="italic"><mrow><mtext>SIRT3</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> <math alttext="m R N A" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>mRNA</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> is broken down rather than translated.• <math alttext="S C plus plasmid" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>SC</mtext><mo>+</mo><mtext>plasmid</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, the <math alttext="S C 1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>SC-1</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> line of stomach cancer cells to which a plasmid was added that does NOT encode the complementary small <math alttext="R N A" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>RNA</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> After <math alttext="24" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>24</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> hours of growth, the researchers measured several indicators of metabolism by an equal number of all four cell groups: glucose uptake, lactic acid production, and the level of cytoplasmic <math alttext="A T P" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>ATP</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> production in the presence of a compound that blocks the electron transport chain (Figure 3). The values were calculated relative to the values obtained for normal stomach cells. Figure 3. Glucose uptake, lactic acid production, and cytoplasmic <math alttext="A T P" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>ATP</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> levels in stomach cells. <math alttext="N S" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>NS</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, normal stomach cells; <math alttext="S C 1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>SC-1</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, stomach cancer cells; <math alttext="S C plus plasmid" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>SC</mtext><mtext> + plasmid</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="S C 1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>SC-1</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> cells with added plasmid only; <math alttext="S C plus R N A" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>SC</mtext><mo>+</mo><mtext>RNA</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="S C 1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>SC-1</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> cells with added plasmid encoding small <math alttext="R N A" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>RNA</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> complementary to a portion of <math alttext="S I R T 3" overflow="scroll"><mstyle mathvariant="italic"><mrow><mtext>SIRT3</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>. Error bars represent <math alttext="plus or minus S E sub x bar" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mo>±</mo><mtext>SE</mtext></mrow><mrow><mover><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>¯</mo></mrow></mover></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>. (a) Explain why an <math alttext="m R N A" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>mRNA</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> transcribed from the template strand of the <math alttext="S I R T 3" overflow="scroll"><mstyle mathvariant="italic"><mrow><mtext>SIRT3</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> gene in normal stomach (<math alttext="N S" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>NS</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>) cells is translated to produce a <math alttext="S I R T 3" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>SIRT3</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> protein of correct sequence, but if an <math alttext="m R N A" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>mRNA</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> were transcribed from the nontemplate strand of the <math alttext="S I R T 3" overflow="scroll"><mstyle mathvariant="italic"><mrow><mtext>SIRT3</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> gene in these cells, it would not produce a <math alttext="S I R T 3" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>SIRT3</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> protein of correct sequence.

(b) Identify a control group for the analysis shown in Figure 3. Justify analyzing <math alttext="S I R T 3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>SIRT3</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> protein level in four different cancer cell lines, as shown in Figure 1. Based on Figures 1 and 3, describe the relationship between <math alttext="S I R T 3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>SIRT3</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> expression and cytoplasmic <math alttext="A T P" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>ATP</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> levels. Calculate the percent change in cytoplasmic <math alttext="A T P" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>ATP</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> levels by <math alttext="S C plus R N A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>SC</mtext><mo>+</mo><mtext>RNA</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> cells compared with <math alttext="S C plus plasmid" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>SC</mtext><mo>+</mo><mtext>plasmid</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> cells.

(c) Researchers analyzing the <math alttext="S I R T 3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle mathvariant="italic"><mrow><mtext>SIRT3</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> gene sequence engineer a <math alttext="S I R T 3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle mathvariant="italic"><mrow><mtext>SIRT3</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> gene that is identical to the normal gene except that a single nucleotide has been deleted from the <math alttext="5 prime" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mn>5</mn></mrow><mrow><mo>′</mo></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math> end of the second exon of the gene; the deletion does not affect splicing. The researchers introduce this gene into normal stomach cells to determine how the primary AND tertiary structures of the protein expressed from the engineered <math alttext="S I R T 3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle mathvariant="italic"><mrow><mtext>SIRT3</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> gene will compare with the protein expressed from the normal <math alttext="S I R T 3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle mathvariant="italic"><mrow><mtext>SIRT3</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> gene in these cells. Predict the results of this experiment. The researchers claim that the data in Figure 3 provide evidence that the stomach cancer cells perform fermentation to a greater extent than do normal stomach cells. Provide reasoning to justify the claim. Based on the information provided, predict the effect on the ratio of <math alttext="N A D H to N A D plus" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mtext>NADH/NAD</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math> in the cells treated with the compound that blocks the electron transport chain compared with similar cells not treated with the compound.

(d) Based on the data provided, explain how cellular processes must be altered in stomach cancer cells compared with normal stomach cells to result in the different levels of <math alttext="S I R T 3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>SIRT3</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> expression observed. A mutation to the gene encoding a cyclin-dependent kinase (<math alttext="C D K" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>CDK</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>) in human stomach cells results in a <math alttext="C D K" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>CDK</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> that is continually active in the cells. Explain why the continually active <math alttext="C D K" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>CDK</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> will most likely change the normal cells into cancer cells.

skill.text: 1.C: Explain biological concepts and processes in applied contexts.
